docs.lead_paragraph: The government’s $1.3 billion program to stop H.I.V. infection in Africa is not cost effective, a new study by a Stanford student shows.

headline.main: U.S. Push for Abstinence in Africa Is Seen as Failure Against H.I.V.
headline.print_headline: American H.I.V. Battle in Africa Is Said to Falter

docs.abstract: Study conducted by Stanford Medical School student Nathan Lo finds that $1.3 billion America has spent since 2005 to stop HIV infection in Africa through abstinence and fidelity was largely wasted.
docs.snippet: The government’s $1.3 billion program to stop H.I.V. infection in Africa is not cost effective, a new study by a Stanford student shows.

keywords.value: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
keywords.name: organizations

keywords.value: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists at an AIDS conference in Seattle said paying patients as much as $280 a year to take AIDS-prevention drugs failed to significantly improve adherence or infection rates.

headline.main: Study That Paid Patients to Take H.I.V. Drugs Fails
headline.print_headline: Study That Paid Patients to Take H.I.V. Drugs Fails

docs.abstract: Study conducted by AIDS expert Dr Wafaa M El-Sadr finds that cash incentives have been ineffective in motivating patients to adhere to their HIV medication regimen.
docs.snippet: Scientists at an AIDS conference in Seattle said paying patients as much as $280 a year to take AIDS-prevention drugs failed to significantly improve adherence or infection rates.

docs.lead_paragraph: The strategy for a new drug to treat binge-eating disorder reveals how a pharmaceutical company can influence the treatment of a medical condition.

headline.main: Shire, Maker of Binge-Eating Drug Vyvanse, First Marketed the Disease
headline.print_headline: Maker of a Drug to Treat Binge-Eating Marketed the Disease First

docs.abstract: Some critics say drug maker Shire is going too far in its marketing of Vyvanse, amphetamine-based drug that was recently approved to treat binge-eating disorder; Shire spent years before approval shaping public perception and diagnosis of binge-eating disorder, much as it did with ADHD in the past; controversy highlights marketing strategy that has yielded billions in profits and that many say presents public danger.
docs.snippet: The strategy for a new drug to treat binge-eating disorder reveals how a pharmaceutical company can influence the treatment of a medical condition.

headline.main: Need to Curtail Smoking Becomes More Acute as Its Known Dangers Widen
headline.print_headline: More Worries Rise From the Ashes

docs.abstract: A study linking an extra five diseases and 60,000 deaths to tobacco use, and the popularity of e-cigarettes, should push the F.D.A. into action.
docs.snippet: A study linking an extra five diseases and 60,000 deaths to tobacco use, and the popularity of e-cigarettes, should push the F.D.A. into action.
